title: In United States v. Microsoft Corp, will the Supreme Court rule that the government can use a warrant to compel the disclosure of records stored outside of the United States?
preds: The Honourable Justices are just as adept at reading the newspapers (or whatever substitutes for newspapers in their lives) as anyone else.  They will wish to begin curbing the impunity popularly associated with internet firms' use of data.
This is a guess. I'm not a lawyer but the site of storage located outside US looks like a scam to me.
Given Congressional action on the issue, the odds of issuing an opinion on the merits has gone way down.
I think they stand mute on this one.
Due to the passage of the CLOUD Act, DoJ (the plaintiff) has filed this week to vacate the case.  SCOTUS will not issue a decision - question will resolve as no.
It will be limited to data collected in the US.
Revising downward on the DOJ requesting SCOTUS moot the case.  Will this resolve the case as NO or will it void the question?
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-microsoft/u-s-government-seeks-end-to-supreme-court-privacy-fight-with-microsoft-idUSKBN1H80T2 the case has gone away, it seems

Congress passing the CLOUD Act has changed the entire landscape surrounding this case, very high probability that SCOTUS does not rule on it and throws it back down to the Second Circuit to be re-heard under the new legislation.

This will be treated as a national security matter. A number of laws, and an entire costly unnecessary federal agency, have been created since 9/11, citing national security. So I expect SCOTUS to say Yes. There is precedent for reaching outside US soil -- such as taxing foreign-earned income, or extending abilities to vote to expats living off US soil, to laws regulating birth of citizens off US soil, etc. There is also an admirable push by some in Congress to properly tax monies hidden off-shore etc. And, practically speaking, if all mega corps and mega billionaires have to do is move things off US soil to avoid US laws, that ends the US budget, the IRS, and a lot of other unintended consequences no doubt! (We are already lawless; this would be the cherry on top.)
The Cloud Act is gaining notable co-authors. Not saying that co-authors translate into a bill passing but there is a bit of action.
They will rule based on the location of said companies headquarters, whichever country they pay taxes too.

Revising down after oral arguments and as legislation, the CLOUD (Clarifying Lawful Overseas Use of Data) Act, continues to gain traction and support from both Congress and Microsoft.  Likely outcomes are that SCOTUS will rule against the USG, and they have the CLOUD Act teed up to pass as a back-up plan, or that the CLOUD Act will pass prior to the end of this term, rendering the case mute.  Either way, revised my prediction way down...

Revise down the chance of Yes before June because the court could just take Sotomayor approach of wait and see and delay it until next term to give Congress a chance to enact a clarification law. On the "yes" camp are Justices Roberts, Alito and Breyers. Justices Kennedy and Kagan are on the fence. Justices Ginsburg and Gorsuch seems to be on "no" camp. Justice Sotomayor takes wait and see, also a No. Justice Thomas is remarkably absent, but in general would side with Roberts and Alito.
A very difficult piece of judgement, trying to match current technology with outdated laws. would be an absolute toss up, except that there is a chance Congress makes the decision moot
Seems that if the court rules against this case, then such a decision begs for firms to store information in other countries.

I'm sticking with my original forecast. Congress needs to enact law regard privacy, ownership, security, and a host of other subjects associated with the cloud. The Supreme Court makes sure the law is applied properly.
i don't believe that this court will extend first or fifth amendment rights to records stored outside the US for non-citizens of the US. I do hope that they will respect these for US citizens

It’s likely in my view that this will fall on the side of ‘no’. There are case by case means of resolving these issues without falling foul of international law, not to mention the unintended consequences of a ‘yes’, which are significant and potentially very damaging (especially if you happen to be a wealthy investor...).

I think consensus is too high. The ones that are overturned on appeal are higher when the cases are criminal but heavily favour the previous circuit court outcome for civil. They are also predominantly decided along ideological lines with conservative bent winning out more often. Also this case and future cases can be resolved without violating willy-billy basis international laws and personal privacy laws by passing an updated law in Congress likely the Hatch-Cloon cloud act.  “In the October 2010 term, the Court decided 86 cases, including 75 signed opinions and 5 summary reversals (where the Court reverses a lower court without arguments and without issuing an opinion on the case).[123][124] Four were decided with unsigned opinions, two cases affirmed by an equally divided Court, and two cases were dismissed as improvidently granted. Justice Kagan recused herself from 26 of the cases due to her prior role as United States Solicitor General. Of the 80 cases, 38 (about 48%, the highest percentage since the October 2005 term) were decided unanimously (9–0 or 8–0), and 16 decisions were made by a 5–4 vote (about 20%, compared to 18% in the October 2009 term, and 29% in the October 2008 term).[125] However, in fourteen of the sixteen 5–4 decisions, the Court divided along the traditional ideological lines (with Ginsburg, Breyer, Sotomayor, and Kagan on the liberal side, and Roberts, Scalia, Thomas, and Alito on the conservative, and Kennedy providing the "swing vote"). This represents 87% of those 16 cases, the highest rate in the past 10 years. The conservative bloc, joined by Kennedy, formed the majority in 63% of the 5–4 decisions, the highest cohesion rate of that bloc in the Roberts Court.[123][126][127][128][129]

Based on the oral arguments, the Justices seemed more responsive to the arguments put forth by Dreeben, than by Rosenkranz. There was less interruption, and Dreeben was able to articulate his points well as compared to Rosenkranz who was frequently interrupted and whose arguments are not geared to persuade justices but present to them as incontrovertible facts. While both arguments have merit, this case will boil down to delivery and how each counsel will be able to persuade the justices. In this, Dreeben, who has argued more than 100 cases before the Supreme Court has had more practice over Rosenkranz who has argued  less than 20. Moreover, the composition of the Supreme Court would favor a conservative, interpretation of the SCA Law which would align more with the government's position.
Based on oral arguments, it's possible that they don't rule on this hoping for Congress to deal with it.

Seems like current laws say this is unconstitutional, needs congress to update. Don’t think Supreme Court will push this through

If they rule this a no every corporation will move all its data outside the US immediately as it is collected.   This is very easy to do.  A no vote would mean that the government could never get any information from a corporation that knew how to set up a data center outside the US.

Yes - SCOTUS does not want to set the dangerous precedent that a US Corporation can escape/evade US law by simply storing its data/intellectual property on a server that is physically located overseas.  As more data storage and processing moves to 'the Cloud', it would open up a can of very messy litigation moving forward, there is no clear 'bright line' to draw, so must fall back to incorporated country.  Note: though it may seem hypocritical, this will not likely change the court's current stance that data stored/processed on servers and infrastructure physically located in the US is subject to our law by virtue of it passing through our borders...

Corporations are legally required to tell the truth, but some do not.

Just a hunch.  The Court may view the recent indictment of Russians for meddling in the 2016 election as demonstrating a need for a farther reach into records that are not available domestically.

Because storing records off-shore is a weasel way to avoid producing them and SCOTUS is unlikely to appreciate that. It will probably come down on the side of law enforcement and security over corporate rights and privacy.

In order for SCOTUS to rule in favor of the government, it would require it to in-effect negate US treaties that already cover the issue at hand before the Court. The United States has standing treaties with nations, including Ireland, that provide a process for gaining access to information that is held/stored within those nations borders.  The DoJ is seeking to abrogate those treaties and compel that such information be provided despite it being against Irish law for Microsoft to comply. Should  SCOTUS side with the government, it would force a number of actions to follow that would be damaging to the US tech sector and could force American tech companies to move their headquarters outside of the US in order to comply with EU and Irish laws regarding data privacy/protection. This could cause a significant loss of tech jobs to Canada, Mexico and/or Ireland.

Between losing the case outright or it being mooted by pending legislation making the rules more clear, the Court will not rule it to be permissible. There are other means of getting the information that cause less entanglement that the Court will rule for.

Though conservative leaning S.C. will likely be torn and want to support law enforcement information needs, it also will want to support the ability to maintain privacy freedoms (and protect critical Secrets) by storing elsewhere.

Court rules require requesting foreign government to enforce  subpoenas, but they can lawfully serve Microsoft, in which case the court will have to determine whether foreign Corp is operated as a separate company with separate tax returns.

I have been low on this question. One of the successses of Trump administration is a reshaping/influencing court decisions (through retirements etc). Given that and argument that data could pass through USA (does it matter if encrypted or obfuscated?) I think simple answer is “yes USA should have access”. There is no absolute right or wrong on this. I’m changing and going with my gut (and a smaller than average brain).
Congress will pass legislation (i.e. cloud act) to make this case moot and the S.C. will drop the case.

It would be difficult for the court to rule on something outside of the US, since that is outside of it's jurisdiction. With microsoft being a US based company then there could be a chance to compel release of information based on its headquartered location and intellectual property rules.

Microsoft is a US corporation with mostly US ownership.  In general, it is subject to US laws and regulations.  Unless Microsoft can prove that the issue involves matters that are exclusively local to operations outside the US and have no effect on operation inside the US, the court will probably rule against them.

A US company was served a warrant for evidence pertaining to a criminal investigation in the US. Though the evidence was physically stored abroad, the US company owned, operated, and controlled the machines where the evidence was kept. Stated thusly, it is clear that Microsoft has a duty to produce the requested evidence, despite potential international implications. If the SCOTUS allows defendants of crimes committed in the US to refuse to cooperate simply because evidence is located elsewhere, it would effectively end successful prosecution of international crimes such as money laundering, drug smuggling, arms trafficking, human trafficking, etc.  The fact that the Court chose to hear this case despite not have a circuit court split suggests that it considers this issue extremely important and will likely vacate and remand it.

SCOTUS will rule against Microsoft because ruling in favor will effectively handcuff legal investigations in the US, all of the evidence will 'conveniently' make its way to off-soil servers owned by US companies.
US based company should abide by US law.

only if they originated outside the US.

It's not a question of privacy or terrorism/national security.  The question is, "can US law be applied in foreign countries?"  This case is about applying old Constitutional Law to emerging technology. New laws are going to have to be created to address matters such as the cloud. If the Supreme Court believes the lower court failed to consider something important in the case, there would be the possibility of them overturning the ruling.   If the man in question was a foreigner and the emails were actually stored abroad, in Ireland, even though search would be done domestically, the ruling would likely still be a no. My initial probability was 15%, but I feel very strongly the end result will be a no.  First source used: https://harvardlawreview.org/2016/12/microsoft-corp-v-united-states/

Oral argument will be held on February 27th, so this case, too, will be decided this term. Amicus curiae briefs are overwhelmingly in favour of Microsoft: http://www.scotusblog.com/case-files/cases/united-states-v-microsoft-corp/ Not that it's a voice vote nor should it be. However, it seems there are international law and conflict of laws (and foreign policy) considerations that favour Microsoft, and those are in addition to the Fourth Amendment argument that Microsoft has. I'm lowering my probability from 69 %.

Firstly, I should state that I am not a US citizen. Whether that is biasing my interpretation of the case, I'm not certain, but it probably does to some degree. From what I can read of the positions, that of the US government (as well as the supporting views of the states) seems to centre around arguments involving what Congress would have intended when they passed the relevant legislation in 1986 had they known the pace of technological advances and that private corporations should not be able to circumvent domestic law enforcement by decisions on where they locate data (which they claim is a purely business decision). The supporting brief by the states seems to also focus on the practice of splitting emails into different packets of data which are stored in different locations, thereby making the current process of international law enforcement cooperation (through bilateral Mutual Legal Assistance Treaties, which the US currently has with Ireland) untenable since the data is moved between locations too rapidly and obtaining the entire email is unduly difficult. Microsoft's position appears to be that Congress in 1986 didn't give law enforcement express permission to do this (not contested by US gov.), meaning that with the common international and SCOTUS presumption against extra-territoriality that Congress should be the one to create nuanced law on this issue rather than using the blunt hammer of the courts (which, according to Microsoft and some of the supporting briefs, Congress are currently doing). In addition, they argue that the US gov. position that the warrant is effectively a subpoena and should be governed as such is incorrect since it treats private individuals personal data entrusted to Microsoft's care as if it were merely business information owned by Microsoft themselves. Microsoft points to the entirety of the relevant legislation passed in 1986 as being primarily concerned with ensuring the privacy of this data from erosion of rights by the courts rather than with ensuring such data is passed to law enforcement.  Most of the briefs submitted seemed to be generally in support of Microsoft's position (although they were not necessarily submitted in support of Microsoft, but rather warning against the consequences of the US gov.'s proposal), such as that submitted by a collection of former national security, law enforcement, and intelligence community officials of the United States, the United Kingdom, and France as well as numerous briefs submitted by foreign governments and privacy advocates within the US. Overall, its clear that this case has a lot of potential repercussions and finding a solution to them all may not be possible simply through judicial review of existing outdated legislation. A lot of how this case goes forward depends on Congress: if Congress is seen to be making clear moves towards updating the existing legislation on this issue, then I have no doubt that SCOTUS will postpone the case or dismiss it entirely. However, if Congress is seen to be either unable or unwilling to do this then SCOTUS could end up coming down on either side: the court is relatively conservative and so may be more concerned with the effects on law enforcement's ability to pursue domestic cyber criminals (which the states' brief is clearly trying to point to, by focusing so heavily on pedophilia). On the other hand, the presumption against extra-territoriality is a longstanding position of both SCOTUS and international law so it may be rejected for that reason as well as privacy concerns. Given the large number of unknowns here, I've opted for a 1/5 chance that the court rules against Microsoft. I would have put it lower, but as stated the court is relatively conservative and a number of long-standing precedents have been reversed by SCOTUS in the last couple of decades leading to a degree of uncertainty about the outcome.

Jurisdiction is the question. Are there enough "contacts" between Microsoft  and the repository of the data to justify jurisdiction over the firm and its records? It is settled that the US has jurisdiction over the firm since it is located with the US. Secondary question is does that jurisdiction extend overseas where the records are likely under the control of a separate juridical personality (foreign corporation)?  Where there is sufficient number of contacts between MSFT and the data as measure by its usage of the data, and such access is allowed by the separate company, jurisdiction will attach and the warrant will be deemed executable as against Microsoft. Factors that will weigh in favor of jurisdiction:  data was gathered from US sources; overriding state interest in protecting national interest.
Over which country is the cloud?

Currently investigative agencies can search US and foreign companies' records as they may apply to crimes within US jurisdiction, hence regardless if the information is paper stored in a file cabinet or digital information stored on a server if a court issues a warrant in the US it may be lawfully executed internationally.This is particularly true as digital information can and is frequently stored on a 'cloud' which may reside in many locales at the same time. In fact the data may be fragmented between many servers to protect its integrity. A physical analogy would be if a memo is ripped into  fragments of one sentence each and shipped to many different physical file cabinets around the world, would a US court be allowed to order the company that is accused of violating US law to be forced to produced all of the fragments upon being served a warrant. I say yes!  But I'm no lawyer.

Supreme Court will rule a warrant can compel Microsoft Corp to disclose records stored outside of the US but the limitations on the procedures and processes in securing the disclosures will be significant and almost not  worth it being considered a government win.

It was proven in Doris Marie Provine: Case Selection in the Supreme Court that the federal government is more likely than any other party to get its certiorari petition granted. I would think as a general rule that its chances of winning the entire case are slightly elevated compared to the average petitioner. Kiobel v. Royal Dutch Petroleum was about Nigerian plaintiffs bringing civil suit against a Dutch company. Jesner v. Arab Bank is about Israeli plaintiffs bringing civil suit against a Jordanian company. This gets tricky in light of the difficulty of determining where electronic records are "stored," since they have no physical existence, and especially when they are distributed across multiple jurisdictions.  The Court will likely decide it doesn't care about the location, real or virtual, of anything--if your company owns it, you must cough it up pursuant to an otherwise legal warrant issued by an authority in the US.  They will probably wish to define all these provisions as narrowly as ever they can, so that'll be interesting.  But I think they'll want the records produced in this case anyway.

Please note: Forecasts in the SCOTUS challenge do not reflect my actual view of the probabilities; I'm allowing self only the options of 0 & 100% in order to make all these close cases more fun to wager my meager forecasting reputation on. Here, I don't really know the issues very well; perhaps it's an unrelated thing but I've heard tell that many of the Justices that get labeled "conservative" minus Kennedy are wary of invoking non-U.S. law in the reasoning of holdings by U.S. courts. Not sure whether they generally take a reciprocal view of U.S. law (or U.S. warrants (issued by magistrate judges)) when enforced abroad nor whether they tend to reach such issues. Initial wild guess (confidence dwindles from left to right in each set):
